about.info: Our database of resources benefits from information collected by these organizations:
about.title: About this site

front-page.p2: We provide information on resources such as free meals, food, legal assistance, and medical help.
front-page.p3: Start by selecting where you are and what you're looking for.

p4.text: We are affiliated with Stanford's {0} and {1} and are extremely grateful to Bill Behrman, Sara Altman, and Cheryl Phillips for their ongoing support and advice.

about.about-us-sources:
Our database of information benefits from data collected by the following organizations:
USDA SNAP Store locator
USDA WIC Store locator
Second Harvest of Silicon Valley
Stanford Pediatric Advocacy

We have a team of amazing volunteers who verify the data and collect any additional information such as additional Covid-19 senior hours, safe curbside pick-up options etc.
about.about-us-disclaimer: This Bay Area Resources project is purely volunteer-driven. We have a team of humans collecting and verifying data from diverse sources. We do our best to keep all the information on the site as up-to-date as possible, however we cannot guarantee that the information is 100% accurate.

p1.text: We are a volunteer-driven, open-source project to help communities navigate the COVID crisis by providing information on public resources. This project began as a {0}, and now provides information on more resources such as locations and schedules for free meals, food assistance, legal assistance, and medical help. We are part of the organization {1}.

p2.text: The development for this project was adapted from {0}.

p3.text: You can find more information on the project, including the source code for replicating the project, from our {0}.

disclaimer.p: This Bay Area Resources project is purely volunteer-driven. We have a team of humans collecting and verifying data from diverse sources. We do our best to keep all the information on the site as up-to-date as possible, however we cannot guarantee that the information is 100% accurate.

pebt.header: Food benefits for kids who get free or reduced-price meals.

ux_study.text_main: We want to learn more about what is top of mind for you at this time and get your input on how to improve the website.
ux_study.text_sub: If you are selected for interviewing,  all sessions will be conducted remotely via phone / video chat, and  we will compensate you for your time.

faq.title: Welcome to Know Your Rights
faq.home_help_text: Select an area below to find out more about your rights.
faq.subcategory_help_text: Click on the questions below to expand answers.

0.text: Generally the protocols for police arrests are not different from pre-COVID times, except that they are more likely to issue summons in the field rather than bringing detainees into a station for booking {0}.

1.text: You can find regular know-your-rights information for when you are stopped by the police at the ACLU Northern California Chapter's {0}.

1.question: What is the status of the courts?

0.text: During a public health emergency like COVID-19, courts prioritize critical cases (i.e. bail hearings, emergency protective orders such as in domestic violence and child abuse cases, and contested quarantine and isolation orders) over other caseloads ({0}).

1.text: You can find the most updated information about operation policies on each court's website for COVID-19 news. We list a few here for you.

2.question: How can I pay bail during COVID-19?

0.text: On April 6, the Judicial Council of California adopted 11 Emergency Rules and established that bail for infractions will be set at $0.00, while bail for technical violations of felony probation, Post Release Community Supervision (PRCS), or parole will be set at $5,000.00. The rules are repealed on June 10, but counties like Alameda have adopted their own "zero bail" emergency bail schedule.

1.title: Someone I know has been arrested

0.question: Can I attend their court hearing?

0.text: Since most matters are being heard remotely through court call and a public access, listen-only line is also available. You can also check the most updated information on each court's website for COVID-19 news.

1.text: See the {0} section for a list of website addresses.

1.question: How can I help them apply for bail fund?

0.text: See the {0} section for a list of website addresses.

2.question: Can I visit them in incarceration?

0.text: As part of CDCR's COVID-19 prevention efforts, normal visiting will be canceled statewide until further notice. This includes non-contact visits, family visits, and the Division of Juvenile Justice. You can find updates on the CDCR {0} for visitation information.

2.title: I am looking for bail fund resources during COVID

0.question: I’m looking for bail bonds for protesters.

0.text: There are many organizations that provide bail fund resources for protesters. We list a few here for you:

1.text: National Lawyers Guild (NLG) San Francisco Chapter Hotline:

3.text: (916) 500-4NLG (for friends and family). Please provide the full name and a birthday of the arrested person.

4.text: National bail fund network's {0} of protest bail funds in California.

1.question: I’m looking for bail resources for other charges.

0.text: You can find bail resources at the National Bail Fund Network's {0}.

0.question: How can I stay safe as a survivor during the COVID-19 pandemic?

0.text: Here are hotlines and support tips for survivors during COVID-19:

3.text: Here are two websites with tips for survivors on staying safe during COVID-19:

6.text: {0} for survivors who are currently in a relationship with their abuser.

1.question: What additional resources and support services are available during the COVID-19 pandemic?

answer.0: The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) provides for an array of resources, including unemployment insurance, additional funds for serving survivors of domestic violence, and housing protections. More information about these resources can be found here:

0.text: The National Network to End Domestic Violence

3.text: Survivors may face barriers obtaining relief payments provided by the CARES Act. The National Network to End Domestic Violence {0} for how survivors can obtain their payments.

2.question: Can I be evicted during the COVID-19 pandemic?

0.text: Your state or locality may have put a pause on evictions during the COVID-19 pandemic. While these "eviction moratoriums" may have exceptions allowing for evictions due to criminal activity or other lease violations, domestic violence survivors have additional protections from evictions. Information on these protections and how to access them can be found {0}.

3.question: I have a court appearance during the COVID-19 pandemic. How should I prepare?

0.text: {0} provides general information about the court process for survivors who are not represented by lawyers.

4.question: Where can I find information on court policies during COVID-19?

0.text: Some courthouses have closed or postponed hearings due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Information on court closures and answers to frequently asked questions involving courts and COVID-19 can be found {0}.

0.question: I am an employee experiencing violence or threats of violence in my workplace. What can I do?

0.text: The protections available to employees experiencing violence or threats of violence in the workplace are generally the same as pre-COVID-19. There are steps that you and your employer can take to address violence in your workplace, including filing a complaint against your employer with the government, and filing for a workplace violence restraining order.

1.text: More information on these and other steps and on different kinds of sexual harassment and workplace violence can be found here:

0.text: Filing for a workplace restraining order in California

1.question: Can I get time off from work to go to court or to get resources and/or support?
